{{Quote|So you forsake your father and his kin, ill-gotten son! Here shall you fail of all your hopes, and here may you yet die the same death as I.|[[Eöl]] to [[Maeglin]] in ''[[The Silmarillion]]''}}

The '''Caragdûr''' was a black precipice of rock that was located on the north side of the city of [[Gondolin]].

== History ==
After killing his wife, [[Aredhel]], [[Eöl]] the [[Dark Elf]] was sentenced to be executed by being flung down the Caragdûr. Just before his fall, Eöl cried out to [[Maeglin]], his son, saying that he would die in that same place.<ref>{{S|Maeglin}}</ref> Many years later, during the [[Fall of Gondolin]], Maeglin had laid hands upon [[Idril]] but was forestalled by [[Tuor]]. Tuor fought with Maeglin and cast him far out so that Maeglin's body struck thrice upon the slopes of [[Amon Gwareth]]. Although Maeglin was not said to have died falling from the Caragdûr, he did share the fate of Eöl in a nearby location.<ref>{{S|Gondolin}}</ref>

== Etymology ==
The name is [[Sindarin]], a combination of ''carag'' ("spike") and ''[[dûr]]'' ("dark").<ref>{{webcite|author=Paul Strack|articleurl=http://eldamo.org/content/words/word-2585526457.html|articlename=S. ''Caragdûr'' loc.|dated=|website=Eldamo|accessed=15 December 2019}}</ref>

== Other versions of the legendarium ==
The idea of Maeglin's body striking thrice was included by [[Christopher Tolkien]] into his ''[[Silmarillion]]'' to fulfill Eöl's words, but it was taken from the Lost Tale of "[[The Fall of Gondolin (chapter)|The Fall of Gondolin]]", which had no premonition nor Caragdûr.<ref>{{LT2|IIIn}}, p. 212</ref> That can explain why in the published ''Silmarillion'' the deaths of father and son happen in different places.

In later revisions of the ''Silmarillion'', Tolkien considered and rejected the name ''Caragdar''.<ref>{{WJ|III}}, p. 325</ref>
